articles.title: About Sachi
articles.description: In my spare time I enjoy snowboarding, watching movies, going to the jiu jitsu gym, and hiking with my dogs!  I love animals especially dogs and cats, however I love learning about different wildlife species whether they are native or not.  I enjoy discussing topics about social injustices, racism and gender inequalities, and environmental justice!

articles.title: Curriculum Vitae
articles.contents:
Education
Masters in Environmental Science & Management, (Expected 06/2023)
Pollution Prevention and Remediation Bren School of Environmental
Science & Management – University of California, Santa Barbara
(UCSB)
Bachelor of Arts in Sociology – Race and Ethnic Studies, (12/2020)
San Jose State University (SJSU)
Research
Researcher – City of San Jose, Downtown San Jose, CA (05/2019)
Recorded quantitative and qualitative data regarding pedestrians
littering habits Presented and organized data using SPSS for 3 project
leaders Helped create solutions on how to reduce trash in the streets of
San Jose
Lead Prototype Designer– Braven, San Jose, CA (05/2019) Collaborated
with 8 other students to present and create a social movement prototype
(#ishareyoushare) for Sutter Health
Experience
Senior year of my quantitative and qualitative Sociology course, we
were selected to help the City of San Jose by collecting and analyzing
data regarding littering habits in downtown San Jose. I also used to
volunteer regularly in various local environmental clubs such as Keep
Coyote Creek Beautiful (KCCB) by participating in weekly trash clean
ups.
Click here for my full
resume.

              BREN MESM Program. I received my bachelor’s degree in

              at San Jose State University (where I am originally from).
              I am a Japanese/American and full-time college student,
              hoping to pursue a career in environmental policy!

articles.title: Snowshoe Hares
articles.description: Differences in juvenile snowshoe hare weights for males and females.
articles.contents:
This report provides an exploratory overview of differences in
juvenile snowshoe hare weights for males and females at three different
observation sites. The sites which are located in Bonanza Creek provide
snowshoe hare data from 1998-2012, and the data is an important step in
gaining more qualitative data on the prey species (Kielland et al.,
2017.) The report also provides data comparing juvenile snowshoe hare
hindfoot sizes and weight in grams.
Data and Analaysis
Juvenile snowshoe hare data was collected and made available by
Dr. Knut Kielland and colleagues at the Bonanza Creek Research (LTER)
network site in Bonanza Creek, Alaska. The data contains observations
for 371 snowshoe hares, collected from 1998-2012. Following exploratory
data visualization, weight between male and female snowshoe hares are by
two-sample t-tests using a significance level (\(\alpha\)) of 0.05 throughout. Differences
between groups are described by Cohen’s d effect size. The
relationship between hindfoot length and weight is explored by simple
linear regression. All analyses are in R version 4.0.2 using RStudio
version 1.3.1056.
Annual Juvenile Hare Trap
Counts


hide

# Read in the data
bonanza_hares_data <- read_csv(here("data", "bonanza_hares.csv"))





hide

# Create a new subset with juvenile hare trap counts that are grouped by year 
juvenile_traps <- bonanza_hares_data %>% 
  filter(age == "j") %>% 
  get_dupes(trap) %>% 
  mutate(date_new = mdy(date)) %>% 
  mutate(year = year(date_new)) %>% 
  group_by(year)

# Create a new table to view the mean, median, sd, min and max for the previous subset
juvenile_traps_count <- juvenile_traps %>% 
  summarize(hare_count = n()) %>% 
  summarize(mean_count = mean(hare_count, na.rm = TRUE),
            median_count = median(hare_count, na.rm = TRUE),
            sd_count = sd(hare_count, na.rm = TRUE),
            min_count = min(hare_count, na.rn = TRUE),
            max_count = max(hare_count, na.rn = TRUE))





hide

# Create a histogram graph with of juvenile hare trap counts by year 
ggplot(data = juvenile_traps, aes(x = year)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 15, color = "white", fill = "blue") +
  theme_dark() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1999:2012) +
  labs(title = "Juvenile Hare Traps by Year",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Count",
       caption = expression(paste(bold("Figure 1. "), "Annual Juvenile Hare Traps Statistics"))) +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.4),
        axis.title = element_text(hjust = 0.4, vjust = 0.3),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.4))




The minimum count of juvenile hare trappings can be seen in 2010. The
maximum number of hare trappings can be represented by the year 1999.The
standard deviation is close to the mean which indicates that the data
points are clustered close to the mean and the distribution is not
spread out very far.
Juvenile Hare Weights


hide

# Create a subset with juvenile hare weights by full sex and full site name
weight_sex_site <- juvenile_traps %>% 
# Rename site names 
  mutate(site_name = case_when(
    grid == "bonrip" ~ "Riparian",
    grid == "bonmat" ~ "Mature",
    grid == "bonbs" ~ "Black Spruce")) %>% 
# Rename sex 
  mutate(sex = case_when(
    sex == "f" ~ "Female",
    sex == "m" ~ "Male",
    is.na(sex) == TRUE ~ "Unknown"))





hide

# Create a scatter plot of Juvenile hare weights by sex and site name
ggplot(data = weight_sex_site) +
  geom_jitter(aes(x = sex, y = weight, color = sex )) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("magenta", "royalblue", "lightblue"), name = "Sex")+
  facet_wrap(~ site_name) +
  labs(x = "Sex",
       y = "Juvenile Hare Weight(g)",
       caption = expression(paste(bold("Figure 2. "), "Juvenile Hare Weights by Sex and Site"))) +
  theme(legend.position = "none") +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.4),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.4))




The graph shows that the Bonanza Riparian site has the most female
and male juvenile hares out of all three sites. Among all three sites,
there is a slightly higher number of female juvenile hares than there
are male. Most juvenile hares among all three sites range from 500 grams
to 1100 grams.
Juvenile
Weight Comparison (Male and Female Snowshoe Hares )


hide

# Create a new subset to find mean, standard deviation and sample size for male and female juvenile hares 
female_male_weight_count <- male_vs_female %>% 
  group_by(sex) %>% 
  summarize(mean_size = mean(weight),
            sd_size = sd(weight),
            sample_size = n())
# Create new subset of male mean sizes and female mean size 
female_mean <- male_vs_female %>% 
  summarize(female_mean = mean(weight))

male_mean <- male_vs_female %>% 
  summarize(male_mean = mean(weight))

# Get the mean values
f_mean <- mean(female_mean)  
m_mean <- mean(male_mean)





hide

# Create a table of the new subset 
female_male_weight_count %>% 
  kable(postion = "center", caption = "Statistics of Juvenile Hare Weights by Sex", col.names = c("Sex",
                      "Mean Size (g)",
                      "Standard Deviation",
                      "Sample Size (n)")) %>% 
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover"), full_width = FALSE) %>% 
  kable_paper("striped", full_width = F) %>% 
  row_spec (0, angle = 0) %>% 
  kable_classic_2(full_width = F)



Table 1: Statistics of Juvenile Hare Weights by Sex


Sex


Mean Size (g)


Standard Deviation


Sample Size (n)


f


855.2154


293.3680


195


m


942.6562


335.2817


160


The table shows the comparison of female and male weights in grams by
mean, standard deviation and sample size. The actual difference of the
means is NA g. The effect size (Cohen’s d) is 0.28. The outcome of an
unpaired two-sample t-test is 942.66, 855.22.
Relationship
between juvenile weight & hind foot length


hide

# Create a graph of Juvenile Hindfoot Lengths and Weights
ggplot(data = weight_sex_site) +
  geom_jitter(aes(x = hindft, y = weight)) +
  labs(x = "Hindfoot Length",
       y = "Juvenile Hare Weight(g)",
       caption = expression(paste(bold("Figure 2."), "Juvenile Hare Hindfoot Lengths by Weight(g)"))) +
  theme(legend.position = "none") +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.4),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.4)) +
   geom_smooth(data = weight_sex_site) + (aes(x = hindft, y = weight))




The slope of the linear regression model indicates that there is an
uneven distribution of residuals. This can also be represented by the
R^2 value, 0.3. The Pearson’s R Correlation, 0.55, indicates that there
is a moderate correlation between weight and hindfoot length.
Summary
The exploratory data reveals the following: - There were the most
juvenile hares in the Bonanza Riparian site -The mean of juvenile male
weights is significantly larger than female weights with a small effect
size. - The weight of juvenile snowshoe hares is linear related, however
the relationship is not significant. There is not direct correlation
between the two variables.
Citation Kielland, K., F.S. Chapin, R.W. Ruess, and
Bonanza Creek LTER. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek
Experimental Forest: 1999-Present ver 22. Environmental Data Initiative.
https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14

articles.title: Willamette Falls
articles.description: Adult fish passage of coho, jack coho and steelhead salmon recorded at the Willamette Falls fish ladder.
articles.contents:
The findings of the report examine adult fish passage of coho, jack
coho and steelhead salmon recorded at the Willamette Falls fish ladder
on the Willamette River (Oregon) from January 2001 to December 2010. The
data is analyzed using a time series, a seasonplot, and annual counts by
species. Data was collected by and made available to the public via the
Columbia River DART(Data Access in Real Time) project.
Citation “DART Adult Passage Graphics & Text.”
Columbia Basin Research, http://www.cbr.washington.edu/dart/query/adult_graph_text.


hide

# read in and wrangle 
fish <- read.csv(here("willamette_fish_passage.csv")) %>% 
  clean_names() %>% 
  replace(is.na(.), 0) %>%
  select("date", "coho", "jack_coho", "steelhead") %>% 
  mutate(date = lubridate::mdy(date)) %>% 
  group_by(date, coho, jack_coho, steelhead) %>% 
  summarize(total_count = sum(coho, jack_coho, steelhead))





hide

# creating tsibble
fish_ts <- fish %>% 
  as_tsibble(key = NULL, index = date)





hide

# convert time series to tsibble and use pivot_longer to reformat
fish_ts_longer <- fish %>% 
  as_tsibble(key = NULL, index = date) %>% 
  pivot_longer("coho":"steelhead",
               names_to = "species",
               values_to = "value") %>% 
  mutate(species = 
         ifelse(species == "coho", "Coho",
         ifelse(species == "jack_coho", "Jack Coho", 
         ifelse(species == "steelhead", "Steelhead", 
                "" )))) %>% 
  select(-total_count) %>% 
  rename(total_count = value)





hide

# wrangling for annual counts
fish_longer <- fish %>% 
  pivot_longer("coho":"steelhead",
               names_to = "species",
               values_to = "value")





hide

# tsibble exploration
# ggplot(data = fish_longer, aes(x = date, y = value)) +
  # geom_line() +
  # labs(y = "Total Fish Counts")



Visualizations
Graphs
Time Series


hide

# explore data with initial graph
# ggplot(data = fish_ts_longer, aes(x=date, y=total_count)) +
#   geom_line() +
#   facet_wrap(~species)





hide

# get species alone and use patchwork
# coho
coho_tab1 <- fish_ts_longer %>% 
  filter(species == "Coho")

coho_graph <- ggplot(data=coho_tab1, aes(x=date, y=total_count)) +
  geom_line() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Coho", y="total count")





hide

# jack_coho
jackcoho_tab1 <- fish_ts_longer %>% 
  filter(species == "Jack Coho")

jackcoho_graph <- ggplot(data=jackcoho_tab1, aes(x=date, y=total_count)) +
  geom_line() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Jack Coho", y = "total count")





hide

# steelhead
steelhead_tab1 <- fish_ts_longer %>% 
  filter(species == "Steelhead")

steelhead_graph <- ggplot(data=steelhead_tab1, aes(x=date, y=total_count)) +
  geom_line() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Steelhead", y = "total count")





hide

# patchwork
tab1_comb <- coho_graph / jackcoho_graph / steelhead_graph
tab1_comb




F.1 This figure shows seasonplots of counts for each
species (coho, jack coho, steelhead) captured from 2001-2010.
This data shows that Steelhead are more frequently passing through
than Coho and Jack salmon throughout the entire time frame. In 2011,
there is significant increase in Coho salmon than the previous years and
in 2009 there is a significant increase in Jack Coho salmon. There is
seasonality for the counts of Steelhead fish however no overall
trend.
Season Plots


hide

# explore counts per species with season plots
# fish_ts %>%
# gg_season(y = total_count)





hide

# season plot
fish_ts_longer %>% 
  gg_season(y = total_count) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "Date", y = "Total Count", 
       title = "Total Counts for Coho, Jack Coho, and Steelhead Fish (2001-2010)",
       subtitle = "2001-2010")




F.2 This figure shows season plots for Coho, Jack
and Steelhead fish counts from 2001-2010 at Willamette Falls,
Oregon.
There are more Steelhead fish passing through consistently over
throughout the year than Coho and Jack Salmon. There is a large increase
in the number of Coho and Jack salmon during the fall. There were the
highest number of Jack coho passing though in 2008 and for Coho salmon
it was 2010. For Steelhead, the number of counts was slightly higher in
2005.
Annual Counts by Species


hide

fish_annual <- fish_longer %>% 
  mutate(year = as.Date(as.character(date),format = "%Y")) %>%
  group_by(year, species) %>% 
  summarize(fish_yearly_total = sum(value))





hide

fish_annual %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = fish_yearly_total)) +
  geom_line(aes(color=species)) +
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_x_date(date_labels = "%Y") +
  labs(
    title = "Annual counts for fish passage by species (2000-2010)",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Count of fish passage"
  )




F.3 This figure shows fish passages by different
fish species between 2000 and 2010.
The counts for Coho salmon remain stable until 2008 where there is a
sudden increase. The Jack coho counts remain stable throughout the
entire time frame. Steelhead fish counts show the most changes
throughout 2001-2010 , with the largest increases occurring during the
first five years.

articles.title: Mono Lake
articles.description: Analysis of Mono Lake levels by year.
articles.contents:
hide

# Read in the Data and Skip the first 4 rows of the data set 
mono_lake_data <- read_csv(here("data", "mono_lake_annual_levels.csv"), skip = 5) %>% 
clean_names()





hide

# Create a beautiful graph
ggplot(data = mono_lake_data, aes(x = year, y = lake_level_feet_above_sea_level)) + 
geom_line(color = "aquamarine", size = 1.3)+
theme_classic() +
  
# Set the range for years and lake levels 
scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(from = 1850, to = 2017, by = 20))+
scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(from = 6200, to = 6500, by = 10)) + 

# Add lake level events 
geom_hline(yintercept = 6377, color = "brown", linetype = "twodash")+
annotate("text", x = 1888, y = 6379, label = "Land bridges for wildlife emerge (6,377 ft)", color = "brown")+
geom_hline(yintercept = 6392, color = "darkgreen", linetype = "twodash")+
annotate("text", x = 1865, y = 6394, label = "Stable level (6,392 ft)", color = "darkgreen")+
geom_hline(yintercept = 6350, color = "purple", linetype = "twodash")+
annotate("text", x = 1876, y = 6352, label = "Salinity above 150 g/L (6,350 ft)", color = "purple")+
  
# Customize color and size of title and labels 
theme(plot.title = element_text(color = "#0099f9", size = 16, face = "bold", hjust = 0.5), 
  axis.title.x = element_text(color = "#0099f9", size = 14, face = "italic"),
  axis.title.y = element_text(color = "#0099f9", size = 14, face = "italic"))+
  
# Assigning names for key 
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Lake Level (ft)", title = "Lake Levels Above Sea Level by Year")+
  
# State Water Board Annotation
annotate("segment", x = 1999, xend = 2004, y = 6384, yend = 6426) +
annotate(geom = "text", x = 1996, y = 6428, label = "State Water Board Decision (1994)",
           size = 3, hjust = "center-align", color = "blue")+

# Mono Lake Reserve Annotation 
annotate("segment", x = 1981, xend = 1930, y = 6373, yend = 6387) +
annotate(geom = "text", x = 1920, y = 6389, label = "Mono Lake Reserve Created (1981)",
           size = 3, hjust = "center", color = "blue") +

# Restoration Orders Annotation 
annotate("segment", x = 1998, xend = 1986, y = 6383.3, yend = 6416) +
annotate(geom = "text", x = 1974, y = 6419, label = "Restoration Orders Issued (1998)",
           size = 3, hjust = "center", color = "blue")+

# First Study of Mono Lake Annotation 
annotate("segment", x = 1976, xend = 1925, y = 6378.3, yend = 6409) +
annotate(geom = "text", x = 1920, y = 6411, label = "First Study of Mono Lake (1976)",
           size = 3, hjust = "center", color = "blue")




F.1 This graph shows the Mono lake levels above sea level (ft) by
year. The key historic events are included as well as the changes in the
ecosystem due to changing lake levels. The purple dashed line represents
the decrease in brine shrimp, which is the main food supply for various
species of birds that rely on them (Eared Grebes and California gulls).
The brown line represents the emergence of land bridges that allows
predators such as coyotes, to access major bird nesting sites. The green
line which represents the lake level stability, shows that the lake
levels have become unstable in the recent years since 1975.

articles.title: Farmer Survey
articles.description: Association between farmers knowledge of NO2 as a greenhouse gas and their response to whether or not they feel they can decrease greenhouse emissions.
articles.contents:
Table 1:  Table 1: Response Questions and CO2 emissions
Awareness 


Question


Yes


No


Do you think farmers can play an important role in reducing greenhouse
gas emissions?


43.43% (109)


56.57% (142)


Were you aware that N2O is considered a greenhouse gas?


66.67% (160)


33.33% (80)


Summary
There is a significant association between farmers knowledge of NO2
as a greenhouse gas and their response to whether or not they feel they
can decrease greenhouse emissions. This means that these two variables
are not independent of each other. The chi -square value, (\(\chi\)2(1) = 25.82) is high,
indicating that there is a large difference between actual and expected
values of the responses to both questions. This represents a significant
association between the two variables. The p-value, which is
significantly less than 0.001, indicates that there is sufficient
evidence to reject the null hypothesis of independence. This means the
alternative hypothesis that farmers awareness of NO2 being a greenhouse
gas and whether or not they can lower emissions are dependent of each
other, must be accepted. The table values and calculations ultimately
show that there is a strong association indicating farmers who are aware
that NO2 is a greenhouse gas are more likely to feel that they can help
reduce emissions compared to farmers who were not aware that NO2 is a
greenhouse gas. The more farmers who know that NO2 is a greenhouse gas
(66.67%), the higher percentage of them will feel they can reduce
greenhouse emissions (43.43%) versus farmers who did not know
(33.33%).
Citation Stuart, D. 2021. Farmer surveys at the
Kellogg Biological Station, Hickory Corners, MI (2011) ver 4.
Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/55eda6881dcf45977626c58e3f24b82e
